awd_titl_txt: Renewal: Mineral Physics Studies under the Pressure-Temperature Conditions of Earth's Deep Lower Mantle
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigators believe they have discovered a giant oxygen reservoir at the extreme pressure-temperature conditions between the Earth's deep mantle and iron core.  The reservoir consists of previously unknown iron superoxides which could suddenly release its excessive oxygen.  In the present project, the team will further explore the different types of iron superoxides, the conditions for the explosive oxygen release, and the consequences of oxygen eruptions.  The sporadic eruptions provide a new, unified mechanism for answering questions on a list of seemingly unrelated past events that occurred during Earth's 4.6 billion years history and shaped the present living planet.  Where did the oxygen in the air come from?  What caused the mass extinctions that killed the dinosaurs and ushered in the mammals?  What was the driving force that pushed all continents to merge into a single supercontinent, and later pulled the supercontinent apart to form individual continents?   From understanding the Earth's Past and Present, we may gain insights into the Earth's Future.

The investigator's recent discovery of high P-T iron superoxides, FeO2 and FeO2Hx with the pyrite-type Pa3 structure has suggested potential paradigm changes in mineral physics and geodynamics of the deep lower mantle.  The team proposes to further investigate the high P-T mineral physics properties of the superoxides, including the incorporation of other major components such as MgO2, AlO2 and SiO2 into the Pa3 iron superoxide, its interactions with silicate bridgmanite and post-perovskite, its electronic and magnetic spin states, and its valence states of iron and oxygen. The team will search for other stable structural types in addition to Pa3 for firon-based superoxides with the apparent Fe oxidation state >3+, and determine their elastic wave velocities for comparison for comparison with seismic observations in the deep Earth.  The team's previous research suggested the existence of a massive amount of oxygen-rich patches at the core-mantle boundary. This research will investigate the metastability of such giant oxygen reservoirs, and the consequences when the stored oxygen is released, particularly the resulting geodynamics of the super plate tectonics that may explain the origin of merging and rifting of supercontinents.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
The lower mantle and core are potentially the most massive hydrogen reservoir in our planet. The role this region plays in the deep water cycle depends on the minerals that can host transport water into this region. The discovery of pyrite-structured FeO2 and FeO2Hx at the P-T conditions of the deep lower mantle early in our NSF supported project ?Mineral Physics Studies under the Pressure Temperature Conditions of Earth's Deep Lower Mantle? created the potential for a new understanding of the role of water and oxygen in planetary evolution. The unusual stoichiometry of this ?super-oxidized? iron compound, and the potential for oxygen release upon its reaction with the core, means that it can potentially have profound effects on how the mantle, and potentially the atmospheric, oxidation state and oxygen content evolved over the course of Earth?s history. In this project we investigated the mineral physics of this new compound but also probed the potential of other phases to host and deliver water into the region with this compound can form. First made synchrotron x-ray spectroscopic measurements of the oxidation state and spin state of Fe, and the valence and bonding of O, to gain a much-improved fundamental understanding of the crystal chemistry of this important new class of lower mantle minerals. Next, we began investigations into what phases might transport and host water in the deep lower mantle. First, we consider hydrous iron and aluminous phases that are known to occur in a structure that may be able to incorporate water even at very high P and T. We first worked in the system FeO-Al2O3-H2O and found the stable form of the high-pressure solid solution between FeOOH and AlOOH. We then extended our studies to include silica-bearing minerals, beginning in the simple SiO2 system because its high-pressure polymorphs also crystallize with structures that are very similar to high pressure AlOOH structured minerals. Further, SiO2 minerals make up ~20% of subducted oceanic crust and therefore could be an important host for water in subducting lithospheric plates. Incredibly, in 2020 we discovered that the SiO2 polymorph, stishovite, can incorporate weight% levels of H2O, even at the high temperatures appropriate for the lower mantle, which is very unusual. This result impacts greatly our understanding of how water, and how much, may be transported into the lower mantle potentially becoming available to form super-oxidized iron compounds. During the last year of the grant, we extended this result to the higher-pressure silica polymorphs, CaCl2-type SiO2 and seifertite, in experiments made to ~150 GPa and at temperatures as high as 4000K. We now have the first data set collected at simultaneous high-pressure and temperature that allows us to constrain just how much water, the H2O storage capacity, these phases can hold at the conditions of Earth?s lower mantle. Importantly, in order to calibrate the water content in our samples at high P and T, which we do from observations of the change in unit cell volume, we made ab initio molecular dynamics calculations that show that the observed volume changes are entirely consistent with H2O incorporation as an interstitial molecule in these structures, a surprising result, and that the H2O storage capacity decreases with pressure and temperature. These results now allow us to develop quantitative models for how much water can be transported into the lower mantle in oceanic crust, to model reactions between water, hydrated and super-oxidized iron and core metallic iron. These results also help us understand the potential for water storage in the deep mantles silica-rich exoplanetary interiors.
